Power to them for monetizing their digital presence and for their digital entrepreneurial IQ (DEIQ). I’d want Medium to provide rankings in earnings, to help us see what Medium’s audience likes behind the paywall. When I transitioned full-time into the MPP, I lost a significant basis of my active followers. My tribe and engagement took a hit, but I am making more coffee money. Medium has afforded me coffee money for life, and that’s an understatement.Writer Jealousy is Normal and Not DysfunctionalSure we are allowed to get a bit jealous of the success of our peers, but I believe our higher purpose should trump all of that. We’re only human. The MPP is a major pivot for Medium’s talent and audience. The reality is as creators and readers we’re still adapting to it. It’s too soon to say if its even viable for Medium’s survival or as writers who want to monetize our creativity. A few success stories or case studies doesn't change that.After the hot face redness of initial jealously, I believe you too as a writer will come to believe as I do. Writers deserve community, support and $. Writers are valuable. Medium is trying to uplift writers and create a great platform. As such, Medium deserves our support.HackerNoon is free to leave Medium, and people are freaking out and burning out as writers and publication managers every day on Medium. That’s just how our days go. It’s normal to have drama in a community with $ involved. Ev can ignore my Twitter comments, I’m not going to take it personally. I’m still going to keep building and writing, in my own way. Jealousy is passing frame of mind, but creativity never dies, so long as you nurture it.The MPP Should be a Community of WritersHowever behind the MPP some of my content that used to get really solid engagement, goes flat. The audience is different and I’d argue, more like a community of writers. Medium might end up more about writers supporting other writers. That’s why in March, 2019 I decided to make a network of Facebook, LinkedIn Groups to creative a positive supportive place for MPP writers.Photo by Thought Catalog on UnsplashThe Medium Partner Program Friends NetworkIf you are serious about supporting other writers on Medium to create win-win/glass half full community support you can apply to join the group here. You can join the Medium Partner Program here.My expectations for Medium as a writing platform were pretty low after writing 800 articles on LinkedIn. I’m likely writing around 3,000 words a day and I’m totally okay with that, in fact, I love it.Full disclosure, I’m not a confessional story writer, I prefer articles that relate to the real world and what’s trending in technology, business, social media and so forth. I won’t hack your emotions, I might just try to inform you. Therefore my ceiling on the MPP is limited, by being contrarian to what Medium Editors recommend we write about. I remember being ecstatic at the simplicity of it all.Your read ratio will be skewed on Medium stats by the kind of articles you write. If you write on writing, sexuality and life lessons your read ratio will be substantially higher than business or technology. If you write more frequently you will see higher green bars, it’s not rocket science. Please don’t take your stats too seriously. I’d recommend focusing on writing what you are interested in and writing high-quality creative work.My 1st year on the Medium Partner ProgramMay, 2018June, 2018July, 2018August, 2018September, 2018I guess there must have been an article that actually went viral in late September, 2018. I’ll have to look that one up.October, 2018November, 2018December, 2018January, 2019February, 2019Here I decided to go full-time behind the paywall.Medium Editors also no longer elevating articles that were criticisms of Big Tech (a form of censorship).March, 2019Medium Partner ProgramWithin the MPP human curators and editors have as much say as the algorithm on how much writers are actually paid. This is due to bonuses.The MMP is an AI-human hybrid ecosystem of audience centric experiences.The audience behind the paywall is much much smaller than the total monthly traffic in the millions of unique visitors. (see Medium’s rank on Alexa here.)SEO is still significant even within the MPP. Medium’s SEO is still so incredibly strong that even lower engagement shouldn’t scare all brands off of it.The MPP is at risk for failure (Medium might not survive), therefore we should live each day on it as if it were our last.The MPP incentivizes writers to monetize their personal brand further and network with each other differently. (It also probably changes what they write about).You can now only get curated (“elevated”) into tags primarily by being within the MPP. Twitter traffic no longer counts to Medium earnings within the MPP.Negative articles are far less likely to be elevated within the MPP, if your name isn’t Umair.The read rate behind the paywall is reduced by around 12%, I have no clue why that is, likely due to a substantially smaller audience for niche topics, and people hitting the Paywall from outside who aren’t members.Within the MPP, the social network effect is way more pronounced. The “who you know” factor on Medium is way more relevant now than ever. It’s no longer enough to be a writer, you have to friend the platform and that’s probably a good thing.Coffee & WritingHow much coffee money did I make on Medium in my first year on the MPP?My Stripe History from the MPPSince November, 2017 to April 2019, I’ve made 32, 947.84 over 17 months, so that’s an average of $1,938.10 USD. Going full-time behind the paywall, my earnings basically went up by an extra $1,000 since February, 2019.In Canada the exchange rate is about 1 to $1.33 CND. So I’ve made $2,500 a month Canadian, which isn’t that much per word considering my ungodly pace. However, it does supplement my other revenue streams quite nicely. Let me be clear, it’s not enough to be an economic incentive but it does “reward” my intrinsic motivation to keep writing.There’s too many articles per month to realistically count them. Still that’s $43.820 CDN lifetime on the MPP. If $3,500 USD turns out to be my new baseline on Medium, that’s $4,674 CDN, (56k), or enough to support me and my Taiwanese immigrant partner in our modest lifestyle and small flat in Montreal.Given I’m a minimalist coffee drinker, my usual order of a Grande mild at Starbucks is about $2.35. that’s 18,647 coffees Medium has funded for me. That’s a lifetime supply, Medium has given me a content basic income and it’s enough for to to tip my hat to the Medium Partner Program and continue putting in my own creativity and time back into the platform.
html:
Homepage
Homepage
UtopiaPress
Sign inGet started

How Medium Pays my Coffee Money for Life

My entry into the Medium Partner Program

Michael K. Spencer
Apr 2

Coffee money is good, right? All writers deserve coffee money. After all, we live on an internet that is outgrowing us and will continue to do so.

Nothing is free on the internet. I too was reluctant to acknowledge and take part in media’s escape from advertising behind subscription payments. But as of February 2019, I decided to put all of my content behind the Medium paywall, basically since Medium’s interface suggested it as a default. This wasn’t an economic consideration in my case, but an ethical one.

Subscriptions are highly preferable to advertising as monetization sources. This is because advertising cannibalizes the relationship with the audience or customer. Centralized platforms that control internet traffic cannibalize the ability of publications to be profitable.

Medium was a pioneer for creating the Medium Partner Program, and while it’s morphing into a new kind of a platform, our very future as writers depends on supporting it rather than resisting it.

Why Paywalls are a Good Thing

For the longest time I would keep the first few days after publishing my articles free and accessible by anyone, and only then put them behind the paywall. My rationale was that I wanted reach (and to support an ethics of freedom) and not necessarily monetization.

However over time I wanted to support Medium and the writers active in the Medium Partner Program. I wanted to trust and support the experiment of what Medium was doing. This is why in mid 2019, nearly everything I write goes behind the paywall, it’s the future of the platform.

In April, 2019 it’s been about seventeen months since I’ve been in the Medium Partner Program (MMP). As one of the most prolific futurists and business news curators, I don’t write to be popular. Behind the paywall I’d wager the audience skews female and young men aren’t as interested in business news as me since I’m an older Millennial on the border of being a GenX member.

Full disclosure, I only survive in the MPP based on elevator (human editors) bonuses, my articles don’t go viral as a rule. I hit a lot of different tags, more so maybe than any writer on Medium. They don’t all fit on my profile page. This is mostly on the basis of being a frequent and prolific writer, than any sophisticated algorithmic outcome. i.e. the way my brain is hardwired to process and explore information.

Top Writer Tags are Highly Over-Rated

Medium Needs to be More Transparent

I believe Medium should be totally transparent about how much creators make with their stories in the Medium Partner Program. In a social media world of constant comparison, I think we should celebrate the success of other writers. If Shannon and Tom, make more in a year on Medium than I will in my lifetime, I’m totally fine with that, it doesn’t take anything away from my efforts at being creative.

If they develop Newsletters or Courses for Medium writers, I think that’s a good thing. Power to them for monetizing their digital presence and for their digital entrepreneurial IQ (DEIQ). I’d want Medium to provide rankings in earnings, to help us see what Medium’s audience likes behind the paywall. When I transitioned full-time into the MPP, I lost a significant basis of my active followers. My tribe and engagement took a hit, but I am making more coffee money. Medium has afforded me coffee money for life, and that’s an understatement.

Writer Jealousy is Normal and Not Dysfunctional

Sure we are allowed to get a bit jealous of the success of our peers, but I believe our higher purpose should trump all of that. We’re only human. The MPP is a major pivot for Medium’s talent and audience. The reality is as creators and readers we’re still adapting to it. It’s too soon to say if its even viable for Medium’s survival or as writers who want to monetize our creativity. A few success stories or case studies doesn't change that.

After the hot face redness of initial jealously, I believe you too as a writer will come to believe as I do. Writers deserve community, support and $. Writers are valuable. Medium is trying to uplift writers and create a great platform. As such, Medium deserves our support.

HackerNoon is free to leave Medium, and people are freaking out and burning out as writers and publication managers every day on Medium. That’s just how our days go. It’s normal to have drama in a community with $ involved. Ev can ignore my Twitter comments, I’m not going to take it personally. I’m still going to keep building and writing, in my own way. Jealousy is passing frame of mind, but creativity never dies, so long as you nurture it.

The MPP Should be a Community of Writers

However behind the MPP some of my content that used to get really solid engagement, goes flat. The audience is different and I’d argue, more like a community of writers. Medium might end up more about writers supporting other writers. That’s why in March, 2019 I decided to make a network of Facebook, LinkedIn Groups to creative a positive supportive place for MPP writers.

The Medium Partner Program Friends Network

If you are serious about supporting other writers on Medium to create win-win/glass half full community support you can apply to join the group here. It has 43 members as of April 1st, 2019 and is a small intimate tribe of some of the most caring writers on the internet.

My Journey on the Medium Partner Program

Medium is a great place to showcase your creative stories and articles and that can actually lead to monetization, brand reach and a freelance writing career. You can join the Medium Partner Program here.

My expectations for Medium as a writing platform were pretty low after writing 800 articles on LinkedIn. Blogging on platforms helped me transition from a tech support to a marketing career. I now freelance, ghostwrite, help startups, do marketing consulting as well as participate on the MPP. I’m a micro influencer on LinkedIn and Medium, I have a niche. I’m likely writing around 3,000 words a day and I’m totally okay with that, in fact, I love it.

Full disclosure, I’m not a confessional story writer, I prefer articles that relate to the real world and what’s trending in technology, business, social media and so forth. I won’t hack your emotions, I might just try to inform you. Therefore my ceiling on the MPP is limited, by being contrarian to what Medium Editors recommend we write about. I’m fully aware of this and respect this and in fact consider myself more of a curator than a creator.

ONE YEAR AGO….

April, 2018

I remember April so vividly I was in Taiwan writing on a scrappy desk in the middle of the living room of my Partner’s parents’ house. I remember being ecstatic at the simplicity of it all.

Your read ratio will be skewed on Medium stats by the kind of articles you write. If you write on writing, sexuality and life lessons your read ratio will be substantially higher than business or technology. If you write more frequently you will see higher green bars, it’s not rocket science. Please don’t take your stats too seriously. I’d recommend focusing on writing what you are interested in and writing high-quality creative work.

My 1st year on the Medium Partner Program

May, 2018

June, 2018

July, 2018

August, 2018

September, 2018

  • I guess there must have been an article that actually went viral in late September, 2018. I’ll have to look that one up.

October, 2018

November, 2018

December, 2018

January, 2019

February, 2019

  • Here I decided to go full-time behind the paywall.
  • Medium Editors also no longer elevating articles that were criticisms of Big Tech (a form of censorship).

March, 2019

Medium Partner Program

  • Within the MPP human curators and editors have as much say as the algorithm on how much writers are actually paid. This is due to bonuses.
  • The MMP is an AI-human hybrid ecosystem of audience centric experiences.
  • The audience behind the paywall is much much smaller than the total monthly traffic in the millions of unique visitors. (see Medium’s rank on Alexa here.)
  • SEO is still significant even within the MPP. Medium’s SEO is still so incredibly strong that even lower engagement shouldn’t scare all brands off of it.
  • The MPP is at risk for failure (Medium might not survive), therefore we should live each day on it as if it were our last.
  • The MPP incentivizes writers to monetize their personal brand further and network with each other differently. (It also probably changes what they write about).
  • You can now only get curated (“elevated”) into tags primarily by being within the MPP. Twitter traffic no longer counts to Medium earnings within the MPP.
  • Negative articles are far less likely to be elevated within the MPP, if your name isn’t Umair.
  • The read rate behind the paywall is reduced by around 12%, I have no clue why that is, likely due to a substantially smaller audience for niche topics, and people hitting the Paywall from outside who aren’t members.
  • Within the MPP, the social network effect is way more pronounced. The “who you know” factor on Medium is way more relevant now than ever. It’s no longer enough to be a writer, you have to friend the platform and that’s probably a good thing.

Coffee & Writing

How much coffee money did I make on Medium in my first year on the MPP?

Since November, 2017 to April 2019, I’ve made 32, 947.84 over 17 months, so that’s an average of $1,938.10 USD. Going full-time behind the paywall, my earnings basically went up by an extra $1,000 since February, 2019.

In Canada the exchange rate is about 1 to $1.33 CND. So I’ve made $2,500 a month Canadian, which isn’t that much per word considering my ungodly pace. However, it does supplement my other revenue streams quite nicely. Let me be clear, it’s not enough to be an economic incentive but it does “reward” my intrinsic motivation to keep writing.

There’s too many articles per month to realistically count them. Still that’s $43.820 CDN lifetime on the MPP. If $3,500 USD turns out to be my new baseline on Medium, that’s $4,674 CDN, (56k), or enough to support me and my Taiwanese immigrant partner in our modest lifestyle and small flat in Montreal.

Given I’m a minimalist coffee drinker, my usual order of a Grande mild at Starbucks is about $2.35. that’s 18,647 coffees Medium has funded for me. That’s a lifetime supply, Medium has given me a content basic income and it’s enough for to to tip my hat to the Medium Partner Program and continue putting in my own creativity and time back into the platform.

  • Medium
  • Writing
  • Blogging
  • Life
  • Self Improvement

  • Michael K. Spencer

    Medium member since Apr 2018

    Blockchain Mark Consultant, tech Futurist, prolific writer. WeChat: mikekevinspencer

  • UtopiaPress

    Discovering the optimal lifestyle of the future.
